free: #n 表示「那個誰呢？」。
#n 表示「那個誰呢？」。
#e Here is a story that I heard from the elders of our tribe.
#c 這是一個我從我們部落族老們聽來的故事。
#e (It goes) not only in our Gluban tribe, but also in Nakahara and Tongan.
#c 這不僅僅是(流傳在)我們清流部落，還有中原部落和眉溪部落。
#e We Seediq.
#c 我們賽德克人。
#n na is used as a particle especially when telling stories.
#n na is used as a particle especially when telling stories.
#e If we die, only our body dies.
#c 若是我們死亡，那只有我們肉體的死亡。
#e What we call “Utux (soul),” whenever it is, does not die.
#c 我們所謂的靈體，不論到何時，是不會死亡的。
#n inu di「哪裡了」。
#n inu di「哪裡了」。
#n 這裡utux指「祖靈」。
#n 這裡utux指「祖靈」。
#e They say, when our body dies, we go to find our ancestor’s soul and then stay together (with them) there.
#c 他們說，當我們的肉體死亡時，我們去找我們先祖的靈體，然後(跟祂們)在一起在那裡。
#n hiya那裡，是指「祖靈之地」。
#e Elderly people say so.
#c 部落的長者是這樣說的。
#e I thought about the story at that time, and said to the elderly people.
#c 我當時想一想，我對長者們說。
#e This is like going to the heaven, which is heard in the church, I thought then.
#c 這就像上教會(聽到)的上天堂，我那時候想。
#e At that time, I heard the elderly taught me.
#c 那時我聽到族老教我。
#n sahayun有人念cahayun。
#n ma mcahaya Dakis ga/kii「為什麼Dakis這麼做這件事？」
#n iya kcahaya/iya cahaya 「不要那樣做！」
#n sahayun有人念cahayun。
#n ma mcahaya Dakis ga/kii「為什麼Dakis這麼做這件事？」
#n iya kcahaya/iya cahaya 「不要那樣做！」
#e I asked a question in reply to the elderly like this.
#c 我是這樣反問族老的。
#e The elderly said, ‘This is not heard from the church.’
#c 族老們說：「這不是教會聽來的。」
#e They told me our own story really comes from our ancestors.
#c 他們告訴我這個我們自己的故事真的是傳自於我們的祖先。
#e Oh, (I) understood.
#c 哦，(我)知道了。
#e Therefore I thought about this story for quite a while.
#c 因此我對這樣的話語想了好一陣子。
#e “It turns out that such story exists in our people,” I thought at that time.
#c 「原來我們有這樣的故事，」我那時候想。
#n kela naq原來是
#n 這裡的kari指有關宗教觀的話。
#e Therefore, I wrote down these words then.
#c 所以當時我才將這些話寫下來。
#e Their words go like this.
#c 他們的話是這樣說的。
#n m-gedang這裡是「死亡」的意思。
#n m-gedang這裡是「死亡」的意思。
#e We Seediq, if we die, we must go through the soul bridge.
#c 我們賽德克人，如果我們身故，我們一定會行過祖靈橋。
#n hako utux也有「彩虹」的意思。
#e Our so-called soul must go through the soul bridge.
#c 我們所謂的靈體必須行過祖靈橋。
#e When we pass the soul bridge, we must have (our) hands examined.
#c 當我們行過祖靈橋時，手一定要被檢視。
#e There will naturally be our ancestors examining (our) hands.
#c 那裡自然會有我們的祖先檢視(我們)的手。
#e Man and woman are all equal. He opens your hands.
#c 男的女的都一樣，他都打開你的手。
#n tae=ta有人會念 tao=ta。
#n tae=ta有人會念 tao=ta。
#e “Let’s see your hands,” he tells tou. You must let him see both your hands, instead of only one.
#c 「讓我們來看看你的手，」他跟你說。你一定要讓他看雙手，不是只有一隻。
#e Then you let him see and put (you hands) in front of him.
#c 然後你給他看，(手)放到他前面。
#e He will examine our palms.
#c 他會檢視我們的手掌。
#n mg-dara「有血痕」；郭老師認為mg-意思是「像」。
#n mg-dara「有血痕」；郭老師認為mg-意思是「像」。

gloss: 使役-通過-受焦-2SG.屬格-3SG.主格

free: #e Whether you are a man or woman, if your hands are blood-stained, he will let you pass this soul bridge. That’s all.
#c 不論男的女的，如果你的手有血痕，他就會讓你過這座祖靈橋。就這樣。
#n denu為dehenu的縮稱。

#n putting ‘edge尾端’, a part of stick-like things (sugarcane, tobacco, scythe鐮刀) left not being completely consumed or broken, the edge of the ground (for example a house located on the north or south edge etc.)
#n tlangan「祖靈之地」，字面上是「成聚落的地方」；alang部落。

#n putting ‘edge尾端’, a part of stick-like things (sugarcane, tobacco, scythe鐮刀) left not being completely consumed or broken, the edge of the ground (for example a house located on the north or south edge etc.)
#n tlangan「祖靈之地」，字面上是「成聚落的地方」；alang部落。
#e If your hands are really blood-stained, you can go from this end to that end, and walk to the place of soul, the so-called gathering place of our ancestors.
#c 若你的手真留有血痕，你就可以從橋的這一端，到那一端，走到祖靈之地，所謂我們祖先聚集的地方。
#n rudan cbeyo「祖先」。
#n tlangan utux baro「天堂」。
#n ani si這裡是「但是」的意思。
#n ani si這裡是「但是」的意思。
#e However, if your hands are not blood-stained, you cannot reach the other side.
#c 但是，如果你的手沒有血痕，你就到不了對岸。
#e When you walk halfway, the bridge will shake violently.
#c 你走到中間的時候，橋會搖晃得很厲害。
#e So you will fall down into the deep stream gorge.
#c 所以你會跌落到那很深的溪谷底。
#n ruru「山澗」；yayung「河」。
#e There is a big what they call “crab spirit” waiting there.
#c 有一隻很大他們所說的「螃蟹精」在那裡等。
#e (It) will eat people who fall down there.
#c (祂)會吃掉落到那裡的人。
#e The meaning of this is, of the people with blood-stained hands, men must be those who have hunted heads.
#c 這個的意思是，手有血痕的人之中，男人一定是獵首過的。
#n mangan tunux也可以說lmaqi。
#e In the past, the so-called head-hunting was to protect the tribe.
#c 以前所謂的獵首是要保衛部落的。
#n kmdakan是指母雞保護小雞的行為。
#e It is not that we hunted heads at will (or) chopped others at will.
#c 並不是我們隨便獵人首級，(或是)隨便砍人。
#n s<m>ipaq也可以用於砍樹。
#n irih so/rih so就像。
#n irih=su=mu so tama/laqi 「我就像你爸爸/孩子」。
#n irih so/rih so就像。
#n irih=su=mu so tama/laqi 「我就像你爸爸/孩子」。
#e It must be like when the enemies invade our tribe or even hunt the head of our tribespeople.
#c 一定像是當敵人入侵我們部落，或甚至是獵我們部落的人頭。
#n tn-alang部落的人。
#e It was like that in the past.
#c 過去的是那樣的。
#n mngu-angan也可以說mnga-angan。類似的變化像是mtaapa/mtuapa ’ride’；mtuheyaq/mteheyaq；mtuheya/mteheya ‘separate in long distance’。
#n mngu-angan也可以說mnga-angan。類似的變化像是mtaapa/mtuapa ’ride’；mtuheyaq/mteheyaq；mtuheya/mteheya ‘separate in long distance’。
#e We hunt each other’s head, so we ourselves must resist.
#c 我們互相獵首，所以我們自己一定要抵抗。
#e Like men must have hunted enemy’s heads, so that we can be tattooed on the face.
#c 像男人就一定要獵過敵首，那樣我們才會被紋面。
#n si means if the previous conditions are met, the following happens.
#n patis dqeras紋面。
#n patis可以指「圖案」、「書」、「文字」。
#e This face tattoo is to let other people see when we are in the world.
#c 這個紋面，是我們在世的時候給別人看的。
#e There is one thing that we people cannot see when living in the world.
#c 有一個東西我們人在世的時候看不到。
#e What I mean is what I just said the blood-staining of hands.
#c 我指的是我剛才所說的手上留有血痕。
#e Men who have hunted heads have blood stain on the hands.
#c 獵過人頭的男子手上有血痕。
#e Although they are tattooed on the face, that is another story.
#c 即使他有紋面，那是另外一回事。
#e Women are the same.
#c 女人也一樣。
#e Women do not go head-hunting.
#c 女人就不是去獵首了。
#e Our Seediq women must work diligently.
#c 我們賽德克的女性必須非常認真工作。
#e In the past, this work was really weaving.
#c 以前，這個工作真的是織布。
#n kii si有「才」的意思。
#n kii si有「才」的意思。
#e Women must know weaving really well so they can be tattooed on the face.
#c 女子一定要很會織布，那樣他們才可以紋面。
#e Our Seediq woman, perhaps since they are little...perhaps when they are seven or so, they begin to learn weaving, until they are so old that they can not see and pull threads.
#c 我們賽德克的女性，大概從...從小的時候，大概真的他們七歲左右開始學織布，直到她們老了，眼睛看不見，沒辦法穿線。
#e (They) do not stop weaving until then.
#c (他們)到那時候才停止織布。
#e Our Seediq women, their life is this long...they live in this world. Weaving and weaving is really what they do every day.
#c 我們賽德克女人，他們人生這麼長...他們住在這個世界上。他們每天只有織布再織布。
#e Therefore, on their hands are really many calluses
#c 所以，她們的手上就真的很多繭。
#n qtehun指「粗」、「胖」；mknedux「厚實的」。
#n qtehun指「粗」、「胖」；mknedux「厚實的」。
#e Their calluses are fat...their calluses on the hands are still.
#c 他們的繭很胖...他們手上的繭很硬。
#e There are these calluses on the hands because you grip the loom to weave every day, “kong, kong” like this.
#c 手上有這些繭，因為你握著織布機每天織布，「貢、貢」像這樣。
#e Women’s hands are also blood-stained just like men's.
#c 女性的手掌像男性的一樣有血痕。
#e Thus, when we are going to the gathering place of our ancestors, we have our hands examined.
#c 所以，當我們要去祖靈之地時，我們要檢視手掌。
#e Man and woman are qual. (They) have hands examined.
#c 男人和女人一樣，要檢視手掌。
#e Whoever are blood-stained, they have really protected our tribe when living in the world.
#c 有血痕的人，他們真的住在世界上的時候，保護了部落。
#e This is the word that the elderly in the tribe taught me.
#c 這就是部落的長者們教我的話。
#e This is different from what we hear in the church recently.
#c 這個和我們近期去做禮拜所聽到的不一樣。
#e (They) say there are heaven and hell.
#c (他們)說有天堂有地獄。
#e They are different.
#c (他們)不一樣。
#e If we think together here...if you...
#c 如果我們一起在這裡思考...如果你...
#n utux baro 耶穌
#n utux baro 耶穌
#e Because I also believe in Jesus, I wonder how they are similar.
#c 因為我也信主耶穌，所以我想他們怎麼這麼像。
#e In fact, there are something which is not the same.
#c 事實上，或許也有一些東西不一樣。
#e My word ends here. That is it.
#c 我的話就到這裡。就這樣。
